reviewText:
One of the first games I ever played on the Wii, enjoyed it on there and now loving it on the pc port!

Pros:

- Beautiful graphics
- Cute characters
- Fun story line
- Easy controls
- You can hug the blob

Cons:

- Sometimes what you have to do and where you have to go next can be a bit vague

A Boy and his blob is a game about friendship. You start off with a meteor falling from the sky so you go to investigate. Once you get to the crash site this white blob jumps out from the meteor and at first you are scared of it but then you become curious and become frends! Once you get back to your treehouse base a jar of beans on the table next to your bed falls over and a single black bean falls out. The blob eats it and turns into a ladder allowing you to climb up to a higher level of your base.

Throughout the game you will collect many different coloured beans that each allow the blob to change into a different form. You will need to use these to overcome obsticles and to safely get a boy and his blob to their next destination.

Also did I mention you can hug the blob?

I bought and played the original 'A Boy and His Blob' (Trouble on Blobolonia) when it was new. I loved it. I could only beat it with a Game Genie, though. I bought and played through the Wii version, also. I loved it for different reasons. One of them being: You can beat it without a Game Genie.

Its 9$ people! This game is adorable, colorful, beautiful, and runs great on PC! I haven't tried it with keyboard and mouse, but it works fine with my X Box controller. Controls are tight and simple. Beautiful animation, music, and sound. So far the port is exactly what it should be.

So what is A Boy and his Blob?

It's a remake of an 8 bit nintendo game that had an awesome concept without the capability to pull it off properly or do it any real justice. Basically, you are a boy who befriends an alien blob that eats jellybeans on a mission to save Blobonia from an evil tyranical emperor. Depending on what kind of jellybean he eats he will become different things. If you feed him a licorice jellybean he will become a licorice ladder for example. You use these various transformations to solve puzzles and traverse the levels. Unlike the old version, you will never run out of Jelly Beans so you don't need to worry about that. You are free to experiment although so far there has been only one right answer to the puzzles. Maybe that will change later on. I haven't played enough of it to determine the difficulty yet. I don't know how tough later levels get.

If you like casual puzzle platformers you really really should have a look at this. I can't understand why this game was not a bigger hit on Wii. :( Anyway, all of this is a mere 9$. Come on! Grab yourself a pack of Jellybeans, sit back, and let boy and blob take you on an adventure!

Oh, and there is a hug button. You can hug your blob, and it's the cutest thing in the history of video games.

reviewText:
This game delivers way more than it lets on.

The first few hours really emphasize relaxation, emphasized by the magnificently crafted scenery. You're toast if you become too complacent though as the difficulty really ramps up later on.

Every level utilizes a different combination of transformations. The addition of a new forms and their uses in conjunction with other transformations really opens up each level to a tremendous variety of mechanics, a variety far greater than I typically see in puzzle platformers. As an added bonus, the collectable trinkets in each level decorate your home base. Kick ♥♥♥.

The one glaring, unusual downside in this game is the lack of punctuality.

Let's say an enemy is about to shoot me and I want to reflect the attack back at him. In order to do so I need to open the jellybean selection window, throw the jellybean, watch the blob chase it down and eat it, watch him become a sheild, walk to the sheild, pick it up, and finally engage the slow-moving reflect stance.

Most games you just press L and you're immediately primed to reflect anything.

By the time you pull out your sheild here though you've been shot, and your single hp is gone. You're dead and you get to start over. Thankfully checkpoints are very numerous and there's no life counter.

If you've got a dozen hours to spare you should check out this wii-shop classic.

By the way only about 1% of the people who started this game bothered to beat it. Not only are you stupid, but you're missing out.

reviewText: As far as I can tell, A Boy and His Blob is a return to form where the original is concerned. I thought it was interesting that WayForward decided to run with this IP, considering A Boy and His Blob is a strangely household name as far as NES games go (at least, it had a few animations in the flash heyday of VGDC along with the likes of Mario, Castlevania, etc.). But it tends to feel unfinished: we have music cutting out at the wrong time, switches not doing what they're supposed to, sequence-breaking, blurry graphics, improper stage tiling, and a respawn point on the second-to-last stage which kills you indefinitely. But my biggest issue with the game is the fact that you need to “call” blob three times to draw him to your position immediately.\n\nAnd if you can believe it, I had a lot of fun with this game. In fact, I went out of my way to do everything there was to do. You drop candy for the blob and make use of his abilities. As the successor to a puzzle-platformer which gained some notoriety in the late 80s, I think it does a great job. This genre is important to me, and the core gameplay is all there. You find yourself considering the inventory in creative, challenging ways. The art style captures the simplicity of an NES game while appearing modern; and that’s great. If you enjoy where WayForward is taking Shantae, you can probably appreciate A Boy and His Blob.

Originally released in 2009 for the Wii, A Boy and His Blob is about, well...A Boy and His Blob. As you control the Boy, you give Blob jelly beans which give him different powers and allow him to transform to help the Boy traverse the levels. This sounds like a nice setup, right? Not so fast. Sadly, ABAHB is quite generic and frankly basic.

Immediately upon playing the game I was annoyed with the Boy’s jumping, or lack thereof. He seemingly struggles to clear the most basic of jumps and movement overall feels quite sluggish. In a game with one hit kills, unresponsive controls are a big no-no. And while there is not a lot of fighting per se, this was an immediate flaw to me and hampered my enjoyment from the start.

While Blob’s powers and abilities are cool and the concept of you, the player, being powerless and relying on the AI to help you is novel direction, it’s undermined by bland level design. Blob’s powers are fun to use but I found myself cruising through the levels without much effort and I never had to guess or figure out what to do next. The uninspired levels cause the game to feel infantile almost. Perhaps the game was meant to be aimed towards a younger demographic and I just missed the memo. But as someone who consider themselves quite versed in platformers and demands a certain quality, ABAHB falls short of that.

A Boy and His Blob is not a bad game by any stretch of the imagination it’s just innocuous and bland, I don’t know which is worse. All of my gripes come from someone who expects my platformers to be competent and well thought out, and I found neither here. I was hoping that ABAHB would lean more towards developer WayForward’s DuckTales: Remasterd (which I loved) than BloodRayne: Betrayl (which I hated). While I would put ABAHB closer to DuckTales I simply can’t give it a strong endorsement.

I enjoyed the 8 bit classic game.  It was incredibly difficult, especially as a kid.  This game (unless it drastically changes partway through) is not that game.  The art style is really nice, it feels modern while staying true to the original material.  The audio...  exists.  Hearing the boy call the blob repeatedly gets very annoying.

You have to stop moving and bring up a poorly working menu to switch jelly beans.  So much time is spent just waiting for the blob to bounce around to where you want him to go, wait for him to get a chest, wait for his balloon to float back over.

Maybe I'm mis-remembering why the original was good back in its day, but this game doesn't capture it for me.  Were it a standalone game and not a remake of an old classic, it would be completely terrible.  Being a remake, if you want to see some updated visual and a mediocre puzzle game it could be worth picking up really cheap.  Not recommended by me.

reviewText:
A great platformer/puzzle game!

The story begins when a boy is awoken by a meteorite striking near his treehouse. When he goes to explore the crash, he finds a friendly white blob that follows the boy back to his tree home. From there, the boy finds out when he feeds the blob jellybeans, the blob takes different forms. Thus, the journey begins...

Of course, the adventure will not be easy. Evil blobs, puzzles, and pits stand before you. You will have to rely on your brains and your blob to progress. The evil blobs are easily disposed of and sometimes they are beneficial. However, some of the puzzles and pits can be a bit of trouble.

There are four worlds with 10 levels each. Each one of these levels has 3 treasure chests that, when all 3 are found, unlock a challenge level for you to play. When you then beat the challenge level, concept art/music/movie is unlocked for your viewing.

Slight spoiler:
There are 2 extra levels in the forest world once you beat the game. These levels unlock 2 more challenge levels for you to play through!

It is really enjoyable seeing a new blob transformation in your bean arsenal. There are over 10 blob transformations (which I won't dive into because I don't want to spoil them). Each one of these transformations does a different thing, and you will need to know how to use each one of them to their fullest to succeed.

The controls can be a bit frustrating here and there, but once you understand how to use them, you will quickly get the hang of it.

The blob selection screen can also be frustrating. It can be hard to select the blob transformations in the corners of the screen. Overall, the system is pretty well polished.

The graphics are pretty good, but, with my computer at least, when I set it to a lower resolution and put it in full screen mode, there was some screen tearing that got annoying. It's not a big issue, but it ruined a bit of the atmosphere.

The music was top notch. I enjoyed every soundtrack this game had.

The story was fun as well. It didn't really make me feel emotions during the few cutscenes, which was a little weak. But I enjoyed the story nevertheless.

Overall, this is a fun, family-friendly game. It takes a bit of skill and a bit of thinking to complete. The journey is worth it. I recommend getting this game while it is on sale, but getting it even at full price is good too!

reviewText: Feeding colorful jellybeans to an amorphous alien pet to make it transform into a multitude of cool items was my favorite thing to do back in  1989. Now 20 years later, The remake is one of the most endearing games of it's kind.. It’s lovely to look at, challenging to master, and undeniably heartwarming!\n\nThat been said,while definately not a triple-A title, heart-warmingly cute hand-drawn graphics and decent puzzle gameplay make this inexpensive game a great value. A Boy and His Blob is a much easier remake of a brutally difficult classic NES game of the same name. In this version, you have unlimited jelly beans and lives, the interface clearly shows what each flavor does, and the game auto-checkpoints before each puzzle. You can die fairly easily, but with little consequence, which encourages a trial-and-error approach to the puzzles. There are plenty of levels, with optional chests to claim; fully completing a level unlocks the corresponding challenge level. The challenge levels rachet up the difficulty significantly, which may appease those who liked the original NES game!

reviewText:
The game presents fun environments to explore and solve fairly mild puzzles in, with a distinctive aesthetic. The controls have some accuracy and responsiveness problems, but the gameplay is simple enough that this doesn't get particularly frustrating except for a couple boss fights and optional challenges. Tributes to the NES original are present enough for nostalgia purposes but subtle enough not to break immersion, and the gameplay doesn't have any of the major flaws of the NES game. Most story beats are very well-presented, and story moments are always brief enough not to interrupt the flow of exploration and puzzle-solving.

The puzzle and platforming complexity never quite take off, possibly because the designers realized the slow pace of the controls put a limit on how intricate things could comfortably get. If you need to be seriously challenged, skip this game (I suggest Escape Goat 2 for that purpose, although its secret-finding and exploration elements are weaker than this game's).

There is no real replayability once you've found all the secrets and solved all the optional challenges, but the secrets and challenges do add hours of playability beyond just reaching the ending. (I took 15 hours to finish everything; I'd estimate it was 6 hours of main game, 9 hours of optional content.)

reviewText:
This game definitely looks nice, but it is far too slow paced.

The hand drawn graphics give the game a nice fairy-tale sort of style, and are very high quality. Same goes for the music.

The problem with the game is the pacing in both the menus, the game and the in-game menus. It's all just slow. I don't mean that my computer can't render it fast enough, I mean it's just paced slow.

For example: This is a platformer game, where the individual levels/worlds are very segmented. I.e. there's no run-off from the end of one level to the start of the next. Now, on its own, this wouldn't be a problem, but because you're sent back to the main menu, which is one of those in-game things where you have to walk around it to navigate it, it kind of breaks you out of the 'zone' of the game.

Also, in-game, I feel as if it takes far too long to switch the blob's tactics. You place a 'bean', call the blob over, wait for its animation to finish, use the blob, then you need to call the blob again once you're done. The large number of steps this requires just feels clunky and slow.

In other words, unless you're a really laid-back person who likes things slow, don't play this game.
